abstracts.cdata!:
The main objective of the Community
            Development Project (CDP) is to provide support to the
            Government of the former Yugoslav Republic (FYR) of
            Macedonia in its post-conflict development efforts aimed at
            fostering reconciliation amongst its people, reducing social
            tensions, and building local social capital. Lessons learned
            from the project include: Post Conflict Reconstruction: (i)
            carrying out small-scale activities designed to facilitate
            the transition from conflict to peace is an effective means
            to post-conflict development; (ii) the active engagement of
            civil society can contribute to a better understanding of
            how conflict can be prevented and actually help prevent such
            recurrence of conflict; and (iii) confidence and trust can
            be restored through self-help interventions. Local
            governments and communities can come together in a
            participatory manner to promote community development when
            they perceive potential common benefits. There is a critical
            need for ensuring that social fund activities are consistent
            with social sector strategy priorities, government reform
            programs, and activities of municipal, Non-Governmental
            Organization (NGO), United Nations (UN), and donor agencies.
            To improve project sustainability, lessons learned have
            pointed to a combination of factors including a strong
            management and administration of project activities under
            the direction of a PIU, institution building at the local
            level, greater stakeholder participation, and decentralized
            monitoring and evaluation. Poverty Targeting: (i) a clearly
            formulated poverty targeting strategy and an allocation
            mechanism based on objective criteria and poverty data
            ensures the flow of project benefits to the neediest
            segments of the population; (ii) the use of a well developed
            poverty targeting strategy and an allocation mechanism will
            mitigate political pressures in the allocation of funds; and
            (iii) a well developed poverty targeting strategy should
            have sufficient flexibility, within the overall allocations,
            to target specific needs on a demand-driven basis.

repnme.cdata!:
Macedonia, Former Yugoslav Republic of -
            Community Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objective of the Community
            Development Project is to provide support to the Government
            in its post-conflict development efforts aimed at fostering
            reconciliation among its people, reducing social tensions,
            and building local social capital. There are four project
            components. The first component funds community investment
            projects including preparing and implementing microprojects
            to rehabilitate small-scale social and economic
            infrastrucutre, and school heating systems; provides school
            furniture; finances community social services; and finances
            small grants programs. The second component builds capacity
            and provides technical assistance at the microproject level
            and at the local government level as well as conducts
            employment surveys to strengthen the local development
            planning process. The third component supports community
            outreach, information dissemination, and project impact
            monitoring and evaluation. The fourth component provides
            support for the general administration and management of the
            project; builds the capacity of and provides technical
            assistance to the project implementation staff; and finances
            annual technical reviews.

repnme.cdata!:
Macedonia - Community Development Project :
            environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
There is currently no environmental
            impact assessment (EIA) legislation in Macedonia, rather
            various laws, and regulations which form the protection of
            the environment, and which need to be updated. Thus, EIA
            functions will be carried out by the project implementation
            unit, responsible for implementing the Community Development
            Project's micro-projects, in compliance with existing
            environmental regulations, linked to a social assessment, to
            be followed by an analysis of alternatives, in consultation
            with local communities, and nongovernmental organizations.
            These guidelines on environmental procedures provide, first,
            the preliminary selection, and appraisal criteria for
            micro-projects, based on an environmental assessment
            checklists' survey questionnaire. Second, a set of
            environmental protection checklists, provide the following
            mitigation measures. The construction of primary health, and
            education facilities, of water supply, and wastewater sewage
            infrastructure, as well as small scale irrigation will
            generate contaminated wastes (including medical wastes),
            clogging of drainage works, erosion of the soil cover,
            vegetation degradation, as well as aquatic and wildlife
            disturbances. Therefore, appropriate waste disposal services
            during construction will be available, with particular
            attention to oil spills, and drainage of hazardous
            materials; construction will be restricted to daytime
            working schedules to reduce noise disturbances; appropriate
            engineering designs, and site selection should minimize
            disturbance of natural habitats, wildlife, and vegetation
            losses; control, and monitoring of irrigation water quality,
            particularly as a result of agrochemical uses should be
            enforced; improved technology for wastewater treatment
            should be available, including monitoring programs. Solid
            waste management micro-projects will comply with the
            adequate design of sitting studies. Involuntary resettlement
            issues should comply with the Bank's compensation
            rules, and procedures.
